messages.content: One guy is generating 4000-5000 rollouts now and it takes 2-3 minutes to just download his rollouts from R2 😂
I think as we move forward one of the major bottlenecks are gonna be rollouts downloads (bandwidth) rather than other parts of the validator.
GM!

@grail・81 

[NEW RELEASE](https://github.com/one-covenant/grail/releases/tag/v0.0.27) IS OUT!

🏗️ **MAJOR REFACTOR** - ~50 files changed, ~10K lines modified

**What's new:**
- 🚀 **Validation efficiency** - single forward pass reused across all validators (no more redundant computation)
- 🧠 **Modular codebase** - split 2,400-line validation file into focused, maintainable services
- 📊 **Cleaner W&B logs** - better metrics with miner context and reduced noise
- 🔍 **Better debugging** - async stall detection with full stack traces when processes hang so we can do root cause analysis way faster
- 🎯 **Reduced false positives** - bumped threshold to 0.51 *experimentally* for soft failures so hopefully you're not going to get rejected for minor numerical differences for some time
- 🧪 **Comprehensive testing** - added lots of tests (15 new test cases just for miner sampling) to catch bugs before they hit production

NO ACTION REQUIRED for miners and validators!

Validators get cleaner logs and better performance (updated through watchtower). Miners keep doing their thing.

PLEASE DO LET ME KNOW IF YOU'RE GETTING ANY ISSUES WITH THIS NEW VERSION SO WE CAN RESOlVE THEM TOGETHER!

✅ FIXED: Validators no longer crash unexpectedly during network reconnections
Previously, validators would shut down when the blockchain connection had temporary issues. This is now resolved and your validators will stay running and automatically retry failed connections.

Let me know if you still get some errors!

embeds.description:
Holy shit\.\.\. Tencent researchers just killed fine\-tuning AND reinforcement learning in one shot 😳

They call it Training\-Free GRPO \(Group Relative Policy Optimization\)\.

Instead of updating weights, the model literally learns from 'its own experiences' like an evolving memory

messages.content: I just came across this however I know nothing of its validity or how it compares to what 81 is doing. What are your thoughts @Oriea
He’s selling prompt guides on the post so I don’t know if it’s actually a breakthrough

I can't make a proper comment now! I need to read it properly first. But I'm not a big fan of techniques that don't update weights! They usually have hard limits in terms of scale and performance and so many of them comes out all the time! This tweet just hyped this one really hard this time...

Will make a proper comment later on.

🚀 **A [NEW RELEASE](https://github.com/one-covenant/grail/releases/tag/v0.0.29) IS OUT!** 

Hey @grail・81 ! We've got a major release that requires some action from miners. Here's what's up:

## 🔥 **Miners - You Need to Update!**
- **Action required**: `git pull` and restart your instances ASAP
- **Breaking change**: We completely replaced `RolloutGenerator` with `AgentEnvLoop` 
- **Heads up**: You might need to do some additional optimizations after this refactor

## ✅ **Validators - You're Good**
- No action needed - Watchtower will auto-update your docker instances

## 🛡️ **Enhanced Validation System**
We've added additional validators to make sure miners are playing fair:
- **Reward validation**: Cross-check rewards miners claim vs what they actually earned
- **Advantage validation**: Verify advantage calculations are legit
- **Log probability validation**: Make sure the logprobs miners send match what the model actually produced

## 🧮 **GSM8K Math Problems - Now Available!**
We've added GSM8K dataset integration for math reasoning problems but haven't switched to it yet! 

**But don't worry** - we're keeping SAT as the default for now. GSM8K is ready to go infrastructure-wise, but we're not switching the network over yet. Just laying the groundwork for future math-based challenges 🤓

Let me know if you're running to any problems.

messages.content:
@grail・81 

🚨 **[Hotfix Released](https://github.com/one-covenant/grail/releases/tag/v0.0.30)**

We accidentally left test code in the validator that was only processing miner UID 80. 

We fixed this issue and made a new release! Validators using docker-compose will auto-update via Watchtower.
where can i check wandb log?
you need to wait for it for 40-50 minutes or so
there was a bug in the validator that I fixed and it's going to be updated soon.

This is my take based on a quick read; take it with a grain of salt:
1. There is some body of work that shows that by doing naive RL you can get huge boost on specific problems using specific models! Given that they only get ~5% improvement on AIME dataset (not showing other ones), I'm not sure how reliable their results are and not sure whether their emprical evaluation is valid. One paper that came out that showed this clearly is this paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.10947! They showed that you just train on random rewards using RLVR and it makes significant boosts for certain families of Qwen models but not all models. 
2. I also looked at their technique and it seems super straight forward! I think I've seen so many variants of it before that they extract specific reasoning knowledge over various problems and they make a database on it they can query from. It's just they labeled it as something like GRPO this time.  
3. I'm not sure why they focus so much on Mean@32 or Mean@5 and they don't do report Pass@1/5/10 etc. Need to read it more in depth later maybe they provided a reason.
4. I think they purposefully show it on small number of examples. I'm not sure how their technique is going to scale as the number of examples increases since the merge, delete, add, etc operations are going to result in so many information loss during the process and if they also end up not deleting that much from the experience library the context is going to explode.

My overall take is that, it's not that much of an interesting work and it hasn't been properly evaluated. Not sure why people care about it so much.

To be honest, I'm not that much of a big fan of techniques that don't update weights. Lots of times they can be practical in short term but they're going to have huge scale problems.
